commands.name: Step 1: Review Deployment with Init Container
commands.description: Review deployment with slow init container and health probes
commands.explanation: This deployment has a 30-second init container delay and both readiness and liveness probes. ArgoCD tracks the health status of all resources. During init, the app will show as 'Progressing' in ArgoCD.
commands.what_it_does: Shows the deployment manifest with init container and probes.
commands.next_step: Deploy and watch ArgoCD health status change over time.

commands.name: Step 2: Deploy the Application
commands.description: Create the ArgoCD Application with slow-starting pods
commands.explanation: ArgoCD will deploy the resources and monitor their health. Because of the 30-second init container, pods will take time to become ready. ArgoCD shows this as 'Progressing' health status.
commands.what_it_does: Creates the Application - pods will take ~30 seconds to start.
commands.next_step: Immediately check ArgoCD to see health progression.

commands.name: Step 3: Watch Health Progression in ArgoCD
commands.description: Watch ArgoCD track health status in real-time
commands.explanation: In the ArgoCD UI resource tree, you'll see pods in 'Progressing' state (yellow) while the init container runs. After ~30 seconds, they transition to 'Healthy' (green). ArgoCD understands Kubernetes health semantics natively.
commands.what_it_does: Shows real-time health status progression in ArgoCD.
commands.next_step: Wait for pods to become healthy, then inspect health details.
info_steps: IMMEDIATELY open ArgoCD UI (use the button above) after the previous step
The init container takes ~30 seconds — this is ArgoCD tracking Kubernetes health in real-time

commands.name: Step 4: Check Pod Health via kubectl
commands.command: sleep 35 && kubectl get pods -n argocd-sc-09 && echo '' && kubectl get application sc09-health-checks -n argocd -o jsonpath='Health: {.status.health.status}, Sync: {.status.sync.status}'
commands.description: Verify pods are healthy after init container completes
commands.explanation: After the 30-second init delay, pods should be Running with all containers ready. ArgoCD health should show 'Healthy'. ArgoCD derives health from Kubernetes resource conditions.
commands.what_it_does: Waits for init container and checks pod and app health.

commands.name: Step 5: Simulate Readiness Failure
commands.command: kubectl exec -n argocd-sc-09 $(kubectl get pods -n argocd-sc-09 -l app=health-app -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}') -- rm /usr/share/nginx/html/index.html 2>/dev/null
commands.description: Break the readiness probe to trigger health change in ArgoCD
commands.explanation: Removing index.html causes the readiness probe (HTTP GET /) to fail with 404. Kubernetes marks the pod as not ready. ArgoCD detects this and changes the app health to 'Degraded'.
commands.what_it_does: Breaks readiness probe so ArgoCD detects degraded health.
commands.next_step: Check ArgoCD UI for the health change.

commands.name: Step 6: Observe Degraded Health in ArgoCD
commands.description: See ArgoCD reporting degraded application health
commands.explanation: ArgoCD now shows the application as 'Degraded' because one pod's readiness probe is failing. In the resource tree, you can see which specific pod is unhealthy. This gives operators instant visibility into application health.
commands.what_it_does: Shows how ArgoCD tracks and reports health degradation.
commands.next_step: Scenario complete! Clean up when ready.
info_steps: Open ArgoCD UI (use the button above)
The app should show Degraded health (orange/yellow) after ~15 seconds
Click into the resource tree to see which specific pod is unhealthy — ArgoCD gives operators instant visibility

commands.name: Cleanup: Delete Application
commands.command: kubectl delete application sc09-health-checks -n argocd && kubectl delete namespace argocd-sc-09 --ignore-not-found
commands.explanation: Cleans up all resources from this scenario.
commands.what_it_does: Removes the application and all resources.
